Regarding https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/14748 opened by @Steve Howell

Would a good starting point be just removing the stream name in the recepient bar and depending on how it looks, we can decide further?

@Pranav Joglekar I think that's a good place to start. I think we'll quickly see some things we'd want to fix, like how we try to align the topic relative to the stream in the navbar, how we draw the left border of the recipient bar etc.

Steve Howell said:

Pranav Joglekar I think that's a good place to start. I think we'll quickly see some things we'd want to fix, like how we try to align the topic relative to the stream in the navbar, how we draw the left border of the recipient bar etc.

Yes. I'll share the screenshots in some time.
Do you mean to achieve something of this sort?
Topic name with design this looks good @Vaibhav Raj Singh
I don’t think we need the pentagon there?
One issue is that when you are switching b/w All messages and Topic that Pentagon will also be switching b/w stream name and topic name

Siddharth said:

One issue is that when you are switching b/w All messages and Topic that Pentagon will also be switching b/w stream name and topic name

Yes. We need something for that.

Topic name without pentagons:
image.png

Topic name with pentagons:
image.png
I personally like the pentagon and how the shape leads one's eye to the pencil and bell icons. Plus it has a messagey vibe to it. I'm in the pentagon camp I guess.

The issue is not pentagons vs. no pentagons, but about what goes inside the pentagons. Our current design language always has streams inside the pentagons and topics outside. The proposal in question has topics inside the pentagons, which is surprising.
Also surprising (perhaps more surprising) is the reuse of the stream-colored background for the topic indicator.

I agree it feels weird and different to not have stream names above each message. And yes it somehow doesn't feel right using the stream colors to display topics.

@Anders Kaseorg , are you suggesting that we not change the current design at all?

No, there’s room to do something here, but we need to be careful. The first thing I would try is removing the pentagons and the colored backgrounds so that the topic names are presented like they are in the unnarrowed view.

If that looks too boring, then maybe we can put a colored pentagon around the stream name in the top bar, or we can invent some other visual cue that we use consistently for topic names—maybe something as simple as an uncolored pentagon with a thin border. But we need to be careful to avoid making the unnarrowed view too noisy.
Of course I haven’t actually tried any of these experiments and it’s hard to know exactly how well they’ll work without doing them.

Let me summarize your suggestions:
1) Just the topic names without pentagons and coloured background
2) Coloured Pentagon around the stream in navbar and topic names like in 1
3) Coloured Pentagons around the stream in navbar and uncoloured pentagons(with a thin border) for topic names.
4) No changes to navbar and uncoloured pentagons(with a thin border) for topic names.

I'll try these and send the screenshots. Anything else we could try?

The issue is not pentagons vs. no pentagons, but about what goes inside the pentagons. Our current design language always has streams inside the pentagons and topics outside. The proposal in question has topics inside the pentagons, which is surprising.

Ah, gotcha. Perhaps just "collapsing" the pentagon could be a minimally intrusive change to the design.
yeah, I was thinking of something similar too.
showing the colored pentagon could be a useful visual cue, while reducing the noise of showing the stream name twice.

My main feedback here is that we need to be really careful and thoughtful; there's a lot of constraints around consistency in the design language, and often a change that appears to help in one place can create other problems. And it's hard to anticipate those problems without seeing screenshots, so we should expect to go through a lot of prototyping and discussion here.

image.png

  • topic narrows look less cluttered

So worth trying to see if we can make it look nice.

How does people feel about the # stream > topic format instead of the pentagon?

We're still playing with this in zulip-terminal, but settled on a unicode triangle instead, ie. design ▶ with stream color background, then regular text for the topic. I could see having a # or similar in there too (or whatever symbol for private/web-public, perhaps)

Valid point.

I don't think we want to change the message header design in All messages ... it's good.

Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but I seem to have noticed that we're trying to lose the pentagon because a lot of new users thinks it looks dated (I for one got an "early 2000" vibe). Besides I'm all for the "reinforce the "# stream > topic" syntax argument.

For streams we can simply completely remove the stream name as well as the colored left border, leaving only the gray message header.

I'm not sure that's a good idea. Keeping the colored border makes it consistent with how topics are displayed elsewhere, things changing too much between different views is confusing.
Yeah, we should keep the colored border at least.

Besides I'm all for the "reinforce the "# stream > topic" syntax argument.

I agree in principle but not in the message headers since having symbols everywhere clutters up the user interface. We should strive for our user interfaces to be as clutter free as possible. A place where this could be added easily without cluttering up the UI is the compose box (where we currently don't show #).

I'm not sure that's a good idea. Keeping the colored border makes it consistent with how topics are displayed elsewhere, things changing too much between different views is confusing.

The borders are connected to the stream name, if we remove the stream name in stream views they serve no purpose anymore.
Yeah, this is why I was thinking we want just a mini-pentagon on the left side of the view -- it can attach to the left border. I think the colored border is a very helpful subconscious reminder.
I think that the mini-pentagon looks like somethings missing.. But that maybe just me.
I'm not sure I see how a sea of colored pentagons is less cluttered than the hashes.
I liked the collapse pentagon idea originally too, as it kind of had a chevron shape. But then it does feel like we just collapsed something, and hide it. As opposed to getting rid of it.
Complex shapes are more clutter than simple shapes.

Regarding how to implement the design, it's probably best to try things out here on CZO. I don't think we want a free-standing # or > in the message headers. I am however uncertain if we should keep the triangles in stream views ...

That's true, but I could lean on the relevance of the slightly more complex shape vs the irrelevance of the simpler shape. But I'm not too worried about All messages at the moment. Although, it might be weird keeping All messages untouched while changing the recipient bars else where.
I thought originally that anywhere the stream name is in the navbar, the duplication should be gone.

I think we can assume that most Zulip users are familiar with the concepts of streams and topics, they therefore don't need to be constantly reminded with visual clues. I however agree that we should address this topic, i.e. get rid of the current redundancy in stream views.
That is not necessarily true for new users.

Of course that's why I said "most users". I would postulate that Zulip currently requires understanding the concept anyway ... if you don't you will struggle with pretty much everything. Adding some # and > won't change that.

I think all the discussion about "All messages" is basically beside the point. We should leave "All messages" alone. There's a large subset of users who mostly spend time in topic narrows, and we should optimize the experience for those users.
Agreed

I think all the discussion about "All messages" is basically beside the point.

I don't think so. "All messages" is also "Search result" and while people might not spent much time there, it's vital that it is clear and obvious, partly because they're only there a short while, and secondly helping users find something is one of the most important tasks. Right now search results looks like all messages, which looks like stream narrow, which looks like topic narrow. It might have redundant information in different views, but it's crystal clear for everyone that it's just different views of the same thing. As soon as you start re-/moving things in different views, you're adding cognitive load on the users.

It's like train station signs. When you've taken the same route for some time, you don't need them as you can recognize the stations but you sure appreciate them when you nod off and wake up and wonder where you are.

A cluttered interface can also deter users from learning it in the first place. "Discord looks so much cleaner let's stay there"

It's a balance. Discord looks cleaner because they don't have topics. And may I mention that our non-technical users around here actually thought Zulip looked less cluttered than Slack, redundant streams notwithstanding.
